instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGOOD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGOOD? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD. When you see ALL_SYS_PWRGOOD, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.SPI_MLBROM_CS_L: What is SPI_MLBROM_CS_L? SPI_MLBROM_CS_L is a signal that goes between the SPI ROM chip and another chip on machines with quad SPI, that can frequently corrode on 13” Macbook Air from 2015 because it is near the corner where liquid seeps in. This being corroded can stop PM_SLP_S4_L from being present. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power Issue
threads.message:
Getting all g3hot rails. Not getting any s4 rails. <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGOOD</SIGNAL> cycles between ~.5V and 0V. 
Any ideas?

Thanks,

Stefan

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power Issue
threads.message:
How are your S5 rails doing?

Voltage of <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power Issue
threads.message:
So..

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> are present.
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.42
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWG</SIGNAL> = 3.42
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is fluctuating between 0 and 2 volts every couple of seconds.

s4 rails are cycling voltage similarly as well.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power Issue
threads.message: So it is power cycling. The usual suspects apply again: <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 8, <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and termination resistors/traces to it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power Issue
threads.message:
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> getting 3.42 volts. All termination resistors test as ok (none failed high resistance anyways) and the traces connect thru on each end.
No issues with pads / traces at <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, chip is getting power. 
I will probably replace <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> with a known working one and see what happens.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power Issue
threads.message: Changed the bios chip w/ a known good one. No change in state at all. Maybe time to throw this one in the bin?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power Issue
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power Issue
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power Issue
threads.message: I still say <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> traces/resistors. HiRes picture of area please?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power Issue
threads.message:
No Title

Here ya go. "Hi-Res"... from the crappy amscope camera. I just need to buy the canon slr adapter.
I checked and double check all of the lines back to the resistors under the CPU. 3.3v getting to all of the pins on the bios chip that need it. <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> getting all of the proper power as well.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power Issue
threads.message: There are a lot more termination resistors than in those pictures. Look at schematic, 16 of them or something. Also check for corrosion on J6100.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power Issue
threads.message:
Checked all resistors on page 61 "SPI Bus Series Termination". J6100 always gets removed and the pads wicked cleaned. I'll recheck monday again maybe I missed one.
I think originally the only visible signs of liquid damage were at j6100.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power Issue
threads.message: I think it is probably PCH or SMC. I'm going to set this one aside and come back to it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power Issue
threads.message: You checked the resistors but did you check the traces?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power Issue
threads.message:
So to revisit.. I have two of these with the same symptoms. Checked end to end continuity of all spi termination resistors and traces.
<CHIP>U6100</CHIP> is getting power, <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> is getting power. 
Could the clock chip go bad? 
Is this a common no fix?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power Issue
threads.message: It is a symptom that can have 100 causes. Is CPU Vcore pulsing?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power Issue
threads.message:
Yes.
The strangest bit - I accidentally disconnected <SIGNAL>SPI_MLBROM_CS_L</SIGNAL> from <SIGNAL>SPI_CS0_L</SIGNAL> and CPU Vcore and all rails stabilize, and the fan spins up full. No display out or signs of booting at this stage - which I do not expect would happen.
I will replace the flash chip next workday to see if it is bad.
